Message.Title: ARM's design are flawed
Message.Msg: Why is Samsung not using A15 in the upcoming Galaxy products? It's because A15 is a power hog and cannot be used in a phone. The big.Little band-aid does not work. Nvidia and Qcom both did not implement big.Little because they knew it would not work. Tegra 4 will not work either. The only ARM SoC standing will be qcom snapdragon but it will pale in comparison to Intel's upcoming bay trail. Watch for a flurry of phone design wins for Intel in the upcoming months.

Topic.Title: Exclusive: Qualcomm-Powered Samsung Galaxy S4 GT-i9500 Performance Revealed

Message.Msg: A Pentium b950 dual core i use, connected wireless to a DSL line with 4 other machines scored 1,893 on Browersmark2.0. The task manager CPU load never exceeded 30% of the CPUs. The b950 is a dual core Sandy Bridge no hyperthreading. it appears that the network pipe will affect the score more than the CPU. You can run it on your machine to compare.

Topic.Title: Apple shares slip more after Cook speech

Message.Msg: I think Apple have kind of lost the plot. Today you can buy a touch screen ultrabook, that converts into a tablet. yes, apple revolutionised the Tablet, Yes, Apple revolutionised the Notebook. Yes, apple have a faithful customer base, who love their OS. Problem is that apple are stuck without offering a Tab-book, because either way a convertable Tablet to Notebook will canibalise sales of their tablets. Other problem is they are trying to convince people their ARM tablet is a viable alternative to a traditional notebook. Oh, please, wake up and face the music...ARM based tablets are good for net surfing and the likes. ARM notebooks are DOA. Macbooks are two years past their best before date. Only option for Apple is to release a Tab-book, problem for Apple is that they have already missed the boat on that innovation. Intel is loweing the power requirements for it's range of processors, every day intel is readying for the next step in their Tick-Tock cycle, next step new processor architecture, on a well proven and years ahead process node. Every tick/tock intel is lowering power consumption either through manufacturing process or processor architecture. Intels appears to be increasing performance where desktion performance power consumption is not so critical. Watch intel roll and push aside their competitors. best thing to happen to intel was the ARM tablet revolution, as this has opened up a huge market, that intel is ready to exploit. Intel will have products more powerful, similar power consumption, more usable with respect to software, and time prove this. It will be interesting to see which read warrior wants to carry either a tablet, notebook , or convertable Ultrabook. My thoughts are the convertable's are destined to suceed.

Topic.Title: Apple shares slip more after Cook speech

Message.Msg: "Apple has always had an uneasy relationship with INTEL..." =================== Apple has always had an uneasy relationship with all its suppliers....because the word on the street is that they negotiate like the mafia. But keep in mind, Apple has also worked closely with Intel: a) during the x86 transition b) it almost went with x86 mobile chip for the iPad (Steve Jobs initially wanted x86 on the iPad and backed off when the iPad lead developer said he would rather quit since x86 had pretty high power consumption at that time c) co-developed innovative technologies including the recent Thunderbolt Now, the writing on the wall regarding fab/process leadership is clear. I don't think Apple or Tim Cook can afford to walk away from Intel. Pragmatism dictates that Apple does a deal with Intel.

Topic.Title: Apple shares slip more after Cook speech

Message.Msg: Now, the writing on the wall regarding fab/process leadership is clear. I don't think Apple or Tim Cook can afford to walk away from Intel. Pragmatism dictates that Apple does a deal with Intel. ---- It's pure fantasy to think that Apple will drop their own CPU and their own SoC for a generic Intel designed SoC. Why? Apples CPU is *good* and is very competitive against the competition (including Intel) and their SoC is different from everyone else as it's focus is on high GPU performance and contains specific IP blocks to support Apples functionality (such as Siri). It will not want to loose control of either CPU design or SoC design. We all know that Intel has a 'fab' lead, but it's yet to show that lead in the LP process - it is *behind* the fab's. There is also the question of how good Intel's LP process will be in reality. In the past Intel's LP hasn't been good as the generic fabs (in terms of transistor density, design rules etc) which add cost and add to time to market. Perhaps 22nm will be different, who knows.

Topic.Title: Apple shares slip more after Cook speech

Message.Msg: Yes, currently Apple CPU is "good" relative to what is available in the market. But we are talking about the future - how Apple can keep iterating and staying ahead of Intel in say 12 months, 18 months, etc. You mentioned 3 issues in terms of Apple using Intel: 1. generic Intel designed SoC 2. high GPU performance 3. specific IP blocks To address all 3, Intel has specifically said that they are open to building custom SoCs - as long as they have an x86 core or transition to x86 over time. So it need not be a generic core. And it can incorporate custom IP blocks. Regarding graphics, Intel has been focusing on this area for huge improvements - to the extent of keeping CPU performance fairly constant - and has indicated huge improvements in the current Clover Trail+ and the upcoming Haswell, Merrifield, and Bay Trail. Regarding LP process, Mark Boyd or another executive of Intel has been quoted as saying that their LP process has been ironed out and doing well. We'll see the results soon enough.

Message.Title: INTC continues to #$%$ more of ARM's turf, Sell ARM say Liberum
Message.Msg: The analysts and the media start changing their tune!!! And this is from the UK, home of ARM. Sweet! ================================= Intel Corp seen making real progress "Intel's announcements and our subsequent interaction with company executives at the mobile world congress suggested that it is making slow but steady progress in its bid to gain share in the ARM dominated smartphone and tablet markets," says Eoin Lambe at Liberum Capital. At this years Mobile World Congress Intel launched its Clover Trail + dual core chipset family (Z2580, Z2560, Z2520), capable of running at upto 2Ghz, but still manufactured at 32nm. Intel claims twice the processor and graphics performance for the product at similar levels of power consumption. Customers announcing support for Clover Trail+ included Asustek, Lenovo and ZTE. "Intel's comments suggested that design activity at larger customers is picking up. Last year most Medfield designs were based on the Intel reference platform which is typical with smaller customers. Currently the company says that internal design activity is picking up implying larger customers, though no customers were named," says Lambe. Intel's single mode LTE solution is shipping currently and a multimode solution is expected to ship in H1'13 itself. Both the integrated solution as well as the 22nm solution is likely to ship only by late 2013 or early 2014. Intel is also shipping in over 20 tablets currently. Liberum believe the newly launched Baytrail product is expected to ship in tablets by Q4'13. While Intel has signed up a number of small and large customers in the last 12 months, actual volumes have been relatively small. "However, we expect volumes to keep climbing through new customers as well as more widespread use amongst existing customers like ZTE, Motorola and Asus. We believe this potential market share gain is not priced into ARM's share price and maintain our sell recommendation on the stock," says Lambe. economy-newsDOTcoDOTuk/shares/share-price-drivers/2873-intel-coporation-and-the-challenge-to-arm-543354

Topic.Title: Apple shares slip more after Cook speech

Message.Msg: " best thing to happen to intel was the ARM tablet revolution, as this has opened up a huge market, that intel is ready to exploit." [As many analysts say that the tablet is cannibalizing PC, your statement is much closer to the truth. The PC may have dropped in sales by about a few percentage points in the past year, but is still higher than the point when the iPad started selling about 2 years ago. PC chips are still selling near 400 million units a year. So they dropped by about 10 or 20 million units year over year, but as you said, Intel has a whole new market to exploit increasing their overall chip sales significantly. As time goes by and Intel improves its mobile chips at an accelerated pace, they may gain well over 100 million unit sales in tablets and smartphones. In fact, Intel is targeting over 50 percent of the smartphone market alone. I don't mention the tablet market, because their will be a cloudy line between the formfactor of the tablets and the laptops due to many being convertibles. And the smartphone market is approaching 1 billion units a year which could give Intel a whole new revenue stream of over $10 Billion a year. Market has Intel not growing revenue at all at the moments for the next 2 years. Of course the reinvention of the PC will allow Intel to maintain a healthy shipment of PC related chips and the huge need for servers to allow smooth performance in mobile products will allow Intel to grow its server base by double digits each and every year for at least the next 5 years. The potential of huge growth is certainly there for Intel, but many analysts still sticking to their stubborn gloomy outlook.

Topic.Title: Intel all in on Linux embedded

Message.Msg: As a development tool Intel System Studo is impressive but if they really want to expand the pool of developers using these tools they should really reconsider that $3500 price. Most small development shops can't afford that. If the goal is to make Intel's CPU's and SoC's perform better than its competitors these tools should be available at a price individual programmers can afford, or perhaps free with some participation in the Intel developer community. The revenue from the toolkit will have no impact to Intel's finances but the long term impact of having efficient code for all of Intel's processors will show up in industry benchmarks and the user experience - and these do hit the bottom line.

Topic.Title: Apple shares slip more after Cook speech

Message.Msg: Yes, currently Apple CPU is "good" relative to what is available in the market. But we are talking about the future - how Apple can keep iterating and staying ahead of Intel in say 12 months, 18 months, etc. ---- Apple controls the full software stack, and thus could fall behind in raw CPU performance to (say) an Intel SoC but still deliver a better user experience and app performance (ios is a native environment, while android is not). Regardless, the Apple design team isn't standing still either, and the current designs are very competitive against Intel and given what Intel has disclosed about Atom@22nm, I doubt Apple will be losing any sleep:) Just having a better fab is only part of the story. Given the timescales involved in designing/developing new SoC's, Apples is years away from "having to switch" to remain competitive.

Message.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)
Message.Msg: wwwDOTphoronixDOTcom/scanDOTphp?page=article&item=ubuntu_nexus_10&num=1 After spending the better part of the past week running continuous open-source Linux benchmarks on the Exynos5-powered Google Nexus 10, the first extensive benchmark results for the Nexus 10 tablet running the Ubuntu Touch Developer Preview are now available. This performance comparison from Ubuntu on the dual-core ARM Cortex-A15 powered device is compared to numerous other ARMv7 and x86 devices. One of the interesting findings from this new round of ARM Linux testing is that the Google Nexus with its dual-core ARM SoC is competitive with AMD's first-generation Phenom Quad-Core processor for some demanding workloads.

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: I like the 3rd paragraph ... "Since last Thursday's release of the Ubuntu Touch Developer Preview for tablets and smart-phones, I've been busy torturing the Nexus 7 and Nexus 10 tablets with a plethora of computationally intensive workloads. I purchased the Nexus 7 and Nexus 10 tablets solely for this Linux benchmarking purpose. In Benchmarking The Google Nexus With Ubuntu I shared some of the shortcomings. The main hurdles I ran through were the Google tablets running uncomfortably warm, the WiFi adapters ultimately going down after hours of use, and the Nexus 10 losing its charge even when using the AC power adapter." I wished they had used something newer than a 45nm, single-core Diamondville Atom. I also have some questions about the generic set of options that Phoronix uses on the x86 parts. Chosing generic options makes it easy to test x86 systems. How would you compare the set of compile options chosen for the ARM CPU vs the x86 binaries?

Message.Msg: How would you compare the set of compile options chosen for the ARM CPU vs the x86 binaries? ---- I'd have to double check, but normally his comparisons are like for like (in terms of compiler versions/OS versions etc). Clearly, some of the arch settings are specific to each CPU family but normally he's 'fair'. For ARM, it used to be the case that you needed to explicitly set the option to use hardware floating point, but most modern compilers now do this by default. Topic.Title: semiaccurate: INTC to lay off 5%; INTC: not

Message.Msg: Was this really the bad news that Charlie had? I like the part of the Brazil R&D article about increasing headcount. This Intel announcement hardly makes sense if Charlie was right. Intel to Invest in Research and Development in Brazil By VINOD SREEHARSHA SAO PAULO – Intel plans to invest $152 million in Brazil over the next five years in research and development, the chip manufacturer said on Wednesday. In doing so, the company will partner with the Brazilian government, which has made increasing the country’s software output a top priority. The direct investment will go toward increasing head count and resources internally but also paying for research at seven Brazilian universities, the president of Intel Brazil, Fernando Martins, told DealBook on Wednesday. Those in the initial group include Unicamp, the University of Sao Paulo and the University of Brasilia.

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: You are correct. The Atom 330 is the only one. All the others are 1c/2t. It was EOLed in 2008. All the Intel CPU on the list support SSE2, SSE3 and SSSE3. The x86 options for "generic" is for a Pentium 4 which also introduced SSE2. That is probably OK. -mtune=cpu-type Tune to cpu-type everything applicable about the generated code, except for the ABI and the set of available instructions. While picking a specific cpu-type schedules things appropriately for that particular chip, the compiler does not generate any code that cannot run on the default machine type unless you use a -march=cpu-type option. For example, if GCC is configured for i686-pc-linux-gnu then -mtune=pentium4 generates code that is tuned for Pentium 4 but still runs on i686 machines. The choices for cpu-type are the same as for -march. In addition, -mtune supports an extra choice for cpu-type: `generic' Produce code optimized for the most common IA32/AMD64/EM64T processors. If you know the CPU on which your code will run, then you should use the corresponding -mtune or -march option instead of -mtune=generic. But, if you do not know exactly what CPU users of your application will have, then you should use this option. As new processors are deployed in the marketplace, the behavior of this option will change. Therefore, if you upgrade to a newer version of GCC, code generation controlled by this option will change to reflect the processors that are most common at the time that version of GCC is released. There is no -march=generic option because -march indicates the instruction set the compiler can use, and there is no generic instruction set applicable to all processors. In contrast, -mtune indicates the processor (or, in this case, collection of processors) for which the code is optimized.

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: Well reportedly, Samsung had an issue with heat on their own phone which is why they decided not to use their own chip and went with a Snapdragon processor. I don't think it is a software issue as much as a CPU throttling issue. It really just doesn't make since to put out a chip that is that powerful but when throttled doesn't really get you more processing power. You might as well clock the heck out of an A7 core rather run an A15 and A7 together and power the thing down to the point that the A15 is really not doing much of anything. Why can't ARM build a true 8 core and gate the cores like Intel does? Seem to me that it is all marketing hype and the phone vendors don't appear to be buying the hype.

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: There are a couple of types of throttling, one protects the CPU from blowing up (thermal) and the other battery. The thermal protection is real low level stuff and would kick in to protect the CPU. The other type of throttling protects battery life, which wouldn't have been important for these tests:)

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: Why can't ARM build a true 8 core and gate the cores like Intel does? Seem to me that it is all marketing hype and the phone vendors don't appear to be buying the hype. ----- They are gated:) It's all about the power/performance curve (A7/A15) and this approach is equally applicable in the x86 world (say Atom/Core). If big/little works in the real world, expect to see something similar from Intel.

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: fyi, Samsung Galaxy S IV, it appears, will be powered by two different processors, depending upon the region, just like its predecessor. According to a recent JPMorgan note the phone is expected to sport a Qualcomm Snapdragon 600 processor in the United States, and a Samsung Exynos 5 Octa in Europe and other regions. When Samsung unveiled the eight-core Exynos 5 Octa at CES, it was widely expected that the Samsung Galaxy S IV would feature Samsung's latest innovation. However, according to an earlier report from SamMobile, Samsung seems to have run into some overheating issues with the processor, and Samsung believes the problem will not be fixed in time for the Galaxy S IV launch. Now, we seem to be hearing reports to the contrary again, with murmurs that both chips will be used. It is noteworthy that the Japanese and North American variants of Galaxy S III ship with the dual-core Snapdragon S4 MSM8960, instead of Samsung's own quad-core Exynos 4 that powered the phone in other markets. SamMobile had claimed to have learnt from its sources that Samsung's next generation flagship will come with Snapdragon 600 inside, clocked at 1.9GHz. Other alleged specifications for the Samsung Galaxy S IV are same as what we had heard earlier, including 2GB RAM, 16/32/64 GB storage options, 13-megapixel camera and a removable battery. Samsung has also released a teaser for its Galaxy SIV launch event through its official Twitter account.

Topic.Title: More A15 benchmarks (Ubuntu Linux)

Message.Msg: Intel did the Core D which is essentially two single cores sandwiched with an interconnect. But it really wasn't a true dual core. Essentially this is what Samsung is doing with their quad cores but it isn't a true 8 Core processor. To me it is akin to having a 2 wheel drive - 4 wheel drive switch vs All independent all wheel drive. They are not truly gating all 8 cores at a time they are gating one processor or the other.

Topic.Title: Great looking picture of Lenovo K900

Message.Msg: here is the same video with a discussion of the results androidauthorityDOTcom/lenovo-k900-intel-clover-trail-plus-benchmark-161440/ The K900 has been unveiled at CES in Las Vegas, where we got to take Lenovo’s gorgeous device for a quick spin. Now, the Clover Trail+ equipped device has made an appearance at Mobile World Congress, and we were curious to see how Intel’s first dual-core mobile chip is doing in the benchmarks. The device we got to try was a pre-production model, so it’s possible that the software wasn’t fully optimized, which may explain why the UI occasionally felt sluggish. We installed v3.1.1 of the AnTuTu synthetic benchmark, which tests memory performance, CPU performance, and graphics, and proceeded to run it on the sleek K900. You can see the process and the results in the video below. As you can see, the 2.0GHz Clover Trail+ processor that powers the Lenovo K900 is quite a beast. The device managed an impressive 25,138, which is ahead of the quad-core Snapdragon 600, which just made its debut on the HTC One and the Optimus G Pro. The Qualcomm chip managed a very good 22,678 in an earlier test. {It was pointed out in the comment section that at 3:15 in the video, you will see the score for the Glaxay S4 GT 19505 was 24317 which is ranked 15th, K900 was 5th}

Topic.Title: Adoption of ARM big.LITTLE Technology Accelerates

Message.Msg: Perhaps because in common workloads the RISC chip requires more instruction cycles than the CISC chip to perform the same operation. Because of this the RISC chip needs to run at a higher clock rate than the CISC to perform the same amount of work. Higher clock rate = more heat = more power. The more the CISC instructions matches the workload the more pronounced this effect becomes. Note, Intel said going forward it was beginning to make design enhancements to its processors specifically for the Android OS. This will extend the advantage even further.

Topic.Title: Adoption of ARM big.LITTLE Technology Accelerates

Message.Msg: The answer is - it depends. One would need to know the exact instructions of the two processors being compared and detailed knowledge of the workload to know how frequently the CISC instructions were being exploited. The benefit of CISC is a function of how well the architecture matches the workload. This is what Intel had mind when they said they'd be optimizing their processors for Android. The same optimizations may benefit Tizen and Ubuntu Touch also but that remains to be seen.

Message.Title: Intel heads into Brazil
Message.Msg: [This is the kind of thing that the ARM world with its fabless concept can't afford to do. And another reason why they can't match Intel's technology. The effects in the marketplace are now becoming evident...] Investing in R&D Intel plans to invest $152 million in Brazil over the next five years in research and development. The cunning plan involves a partnership with the Brazilian government, which has made increasing the country’s software output a top priority. The direct investment will go toward increasing staff numbers and resources internally but also paying for research at seven Brazilian universities. The Brazilian government is expected to match Intel’s investment. This follows a statement from President Dilma Rousseff last year which said the Brazilian government would spend at least $254 million to stimulate software development. That figure is seed finance for the scheme and is expected to grow. It does not include Brazil’s national development bank’s initiatives. Brazil is Intel’s third-largest market and its venture capital arm, Intel Capital, has invested approximately $100 million in more than 25 companies in the area. From Fudzilla ["The cunning plan involves a partnership with the Brazilian government..."]

Topic.Title: Adoption of ARM big.LITTLE Technology Accelerates

"The benefit of CISC is a function of how well the architecture matches the workload. " INsightful... The benefit of any architecture "This is what Intel had mind when they said they'd be optimizing their processors" Is optimizing their processors unique to INtel...

Message.Title: Samsung answers question from Intel and Apple engineers at the ISSCC
Message.Msg: eetimesDOTcom/electronics-news/4407832/Slideshow--Mobile-at-ISSCC-with-Samsung--Mediatek Slideshow: Samsung cagey on smartphone SoC at ISSCC How do you know when to switch between the big bank of A15s and the little bank of A7s, asked the ADI engineer in a counter-punch. “I am just a circuit engineer, not the software guy--they can explain about this,” he said, again deflecting the question and getting a laugh from the audience. Samsung’s answers were actually very revealing, according to David Kanter, a blogger and analyst of processor technology. “The fact that the switching is controlled at the software level tells you it’s slow,” he said.

Message.Title: Another Day
Message.Msg: Another day of ARM being down more than Intel. Another day closer to the release of Haswell. Another day closer to release of Intel 14nm FinFET products. Another day closer to announcement of another big Intel deal and partnership. Technicals indicate that ARM buyers are exhausted and Intel is ready to move up.This trend just needs one more tiny spark to lite it on fire in earnest. There are so many great possibilities. One of the major dynamics out of MWC 2013 was the absence of any noteworthy high-end phones - the kind of phones that ARM has to have to maintain its huge P/E ratio. The tipping point finally appears to be upon us as Intel is now reining blows onto ARMs sensitivities from all directions. All ARM with its fading fabrication can hope to do at this point is cover up and hang on.This will probably continue until Intel's 14nm production arrives, signaling that the fight is officially over...

Topic.Title: Question for everyone

Message.Msg: Intel needs Bay Trail to excel in performance and performance per watt. If it can show that, then game over for the majority of the "me too" undifferentiated ARM folks. Qualcomm is left standing, Nvidia probably can take enough market share to be relevant, and Intel will leverage the full extent of its manufacturing and architecture prowess to take the lion's share of the tablet/phone market. It's really only a matter of time.
